<171hp 302m 206mv> 
help
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Avendar: The Crucible of Legends -- Help                         |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

You can get a help on a variety of topics to guide you through the playing
of Avendar.  Simply type help '<subject>' to gain help on a certain topic.
Here's a list of general topics you can search for help on to get you
started:

GETTING STARTED - The basics of Avendar and MUDding in general.
INFORMATION - How to get info on yourself and your surroundings.
MOVING AROUND - How to move around in the world of Avendar.
INTERACTION - How to interact with objects and items in Avendar.
COMMUNICATION - How to communicate with others in Avendar.
GROUPING - How to group together with others in Avendar.
COMBAT - How to engage (and survive!) combat in Avendar.
OVERVIEW - An overview of the basic Avendar commands (old help).

Be sure to pay attention to the "See Also" located at the bottom of many of
the helpfiles, as they often point to other useful pieces of information on
the topic you're reading on.

If you are stuck or confused and cannot find help on a certain topic, please
read 'help PRAY' for instructions on how to contact an immortal who may be
able to help you.

<171hp 302m 206mv> 
help overview
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          GENERAL HELP                                                     |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

 north south east west up mercy      follow group gtell split
 recall open close consider         /---------------------------------\
 sleep wake rest stand sit          |  INFORMATION & COMMUNICATION    |
 flee kill murder kick rescue       \---------------------------------/
 backstab cast wimpy disarm          emote smote pmote who where scan
 assume focus damage death           say esay tell gtell yell ooc pray
/--------------------------------\   help note commands areas exits
|  OBJECTS                       |   worth report score time weather 
\--------------------------------/   look description description2  
 get put drop give sacrifice         background background2 editor
 wear wield hold eat drink fill     /---------------------------------\ 
 recite quaff zap brandish          |  OTHER                          |
 lock unlock open close pick        \---------------------------------/
 inventory equipment look compare    ! save quit practice train gain
 list buy sell value                 password disbelieve bug 

/---------------------------------------------------------------------\
|  For more help, type 'help <topic>' for any command/skill/spell.    |
|  ALSO see help on:  RULES STORY EXPERIENCE NEWS TICK WIZLIST        |
|  HOUSE RELIGION ROLEPLAYING PLAYERKILLING NEWBIE REALISM            |
|  NAME ALIGNMENT ALIGNMENT2 MULTICHARING LANGUAGE                    |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------/

<171hp 302m 206mv> 
help story
In the beginning, were the gods. Some to create,
some to destroy, some to taint, others to bring
hope, others to simply be. The gods, though, were
alone in the universe. Seeking a canvas for their
essence, they created the world of Avendar.
And, edged along ever so carefully by the gods
of creation, they created the alatharya,
FirstChildren of the gods. 

To the alatharya, the gods gave their greatest
gift - Magic. Magic to create, magic to destroy,
magic, some portion of each of the gods'
essences was sent to swirl through the prime
material, creating the ether from which mages
drew. 

As time passed, the alatharya waxed mighty. The
gods, pleased, began plans for other creations,
each mighty in their own way. But the Alatharya
were not content with the god's plans to make
others - jealous of the thought that other
children might bring the god's attention away
from them, and coveting the Quintessence, they
sought to steal the power of the gods. With their
mighty pyramids, and strange rites, their priests
and scholars came together one fateful night for
a grand theft. In their hubris, they sought to
steal the power of the gods for themselves, and
make of themselves Creators. 

But, alas, it was not to be. The gods knew of the
theft, and instead of invoking the power of the
gods, they invoked their deepest and darkest
wrath. All across Avendar, the great cities of the
alatharya were rent in blood and fire - their
libraries burned, their pyramids turned to
rubble, their homes driven to the four winds. The
revenge of a god is not a small thing, and the
revenge of the combined might of a pantheon can
level entire worlds. So it was that the Alatharya
were cast from their pinnacle as the mightiest of
races. No more would the minds of the Alatharya
follow the intricacies of magic - nor would the
Alatharya do naught than strive for balance in
their day to day life, fearful of retribution for
their ancient crime. And, lastly, the gods
sundered Magic from its pure form into its
elemental components. Water, Spirit, Wind, Fire,
Void, and Earth did it break them, and forever
shatter the mortal dream of attaining the divine
through mystic arts. 

This sundering of the Magic released cataclysmic
storms of magic over the surface of Avendar, which
changed and altered all that they touched. Of the
god's new children, vast changes were wrought,
some for good, some for ill. The aelin were
granted flight, and the gift of keen reason. The
caldarans learned wisdom, and were turned from
the night. At the same time, the brutal srryn
were born, spawn of languid swamp and foul
hearts. Beneath the earth fled the shuddeni,
blind minions of pure darkness, driven mad, some
say, by a love of much knowledge. 

The centuries after the Sundering of Magic were
dark ones. It was not until some hundreds of
years that civilization began anew, with the proud
aelin and their cities in the skies. Striving,
perhaps, for a memory of things past, they
collected the artifacts of the ancient alatharya,
and built cities that at least faintly echoed the
glories of ancient days. 

And so it was the aelin waxed powerful, the
srryn confined to their torpid swamps and the
shuddeni to their caves, and all others brought
into alliance with them. For a time, it appeared the
world would never again know such a destruction,
until, at last, the gods allowed a new race to
awaken on Avendar - the humans. 

The humans were taken by any and all things,
some easily swayed to evil, others relentless
paragons of virtue. Some claimed them akin to
gods, others to devil-spawn of the Void, others
still to reckless children. Nevertheless, the
passion that drove the humans lead them, at first,
into a reckless alliance with the brutal srryn. 

In their midnight rituals, the srryn had learned
much of the ways of fire. Fire to burn, fire to
make their will be done - fire, to destroy. The
humans, always more keen of wit, seized the
secrets of the srryn fire shamans, cultivated
among their numbers the first Scholars of Fire.
Savage men, of an unholy taste for pleasure and
power, unleashed their magics across the surface
of Avendar. 

Securing the yoke about their fellow men, the
great Scholars of Fire also trained warlords, or
templars of fire, to command in battle with the
sword, and yet still reign destruction with the
forces of fire. Most of the races scattered
before the hordes of humans and srryn that
plundered all they found, but the aelin stood to
defend their cities, and forged an alliance to
fight to keep the humans at bay, lest the night
consume all. 

Cities were reduced to ash. Aelin died in droves,
using their already small collection of ancient
artifacts to drive the humans back. And yet, again
and again the humans surged forward. Quick to
breed, quick to die, the humans stood at the
verge of a destruction that would consume all. 

Fortunately, not all among the humans thought as
the Scholars of Fire. Small in number, but
present, were humans who sought meaning in
more than brute destruction. Groping blindly,
they sought to bring peace, to heal, to purify.
They craved a life spent in other activity than
blind devotion to an orgy of chaos and
destruction. 

Praying to the gods, they were answered. Jolinn,
Father of the Seas, Lord of the Sapphire Spear,
sent these brave few to seek the titans, who
dwelt high in the mountains, where they had
slumbered since the Sundering. Waking, they
taught the humans of the magics of Water, and of
the strength of the Seas. These humans
returned, and became the first of the Scholars
of Water. Born to bring healing to a troubled
land, their love of life quenched the inferno of the
fire mage's hate. With their aid, the aelin drove
the armies of Fire back to the swamps, where
most of the Scholars of Fire were put to the
sword. 

Thus ended what the chronicles tell of as the War
of Fire, when men nearly brought ruin once more
to the world. 

And yet, the aelin were not the ones to come to
dominance after the war. The humans, their
passion driving them still, slowly grew in numbers
across the surface of Avendar, while the aelin
remained in their cities, lost in the intricacies of
their own life. 

Those humans not already devoted to healing
learned much of the ways of earth from the god
Iandir, who brought law once more to the hills and
valleys of Avendar. Men paused in their mad
growth, and built cities, homes, places of staying,
order, and protection. 

And thus, many thousands of years passed.
Quarrels came and went, but none so great as a
war to drench and entire world in Fire. And so it
was that the empire of the Humans subsumed the
entire world. And yet, the humans were drawn to
more than just the surface, and began their
explorations of the nether regions of Avendar.
There, they found the great cities of the
shuddeni, a race blinded by the night, but who
still saw much, and gloried in the horror of the
demon sultans who taught them. 

Here, human scholars went who wished to learn
more. Tortured they were by the shuddeni, but
some, a few, learned their ways. Combining the
ritual of the shuddeni with the ancient learning of
the humans, the discipline of the Void was born. 

Who can say why the gods suffer such things to
exist? Certainly, the gods of the dark revel in the
Void, the Things which inhabit it not always of
their own creation, but often after their own
heart. Certainly, what the Scholars of the Void
did was the antithesis of life, and everything
living, but the gods of light could not bring and
end to them without disturbing the balance of the
world. 

So it was, those humans who studied with the
Shuddeni waxed mighty in their counsels, and
taught the shuddeni much of the ways of war. The
shuddeni culture, grown stagnant in their
millennia under stone, was re-energized by the
promise of conquest above the surface. On the
blackest night, of the darkest day of the year,
the humans and their shuddeni allies rode forth
from the caves of their dank abyss, to usher in an
age of Night the world had never known. 

Striking with meaning, order, and purpose rather
than out of blind rage, the forces of the Void
took cities, rather than burning them, and
corrupted them to their will. Mothers were
forced to offer their children as appeasement in
unholy rites, designed to serve the Things which
dwell beyond, some were kept as slaves, but the
cities under the sway of the Void lived, even if
they were more the corpses of cities than
anything resembling a living organism. 

The templars of water mounted counter-assault
after counter-assault. Some times, with success,
other times, with failures. For long 
years, the two sides held sway in a series of
enormous battles. With time, thought, the
Scholars of Water found their magic growing
weaker - the Things of the void had grown strong
on the flesh of the young, and pressed for more
mortal flesh. When all seem darkest, when even
great Earandam thought to send its children to
the aelin amidst the mountain, the unthinkable
happened in the ranks of the Void. 

Their dark rites prepared, their rituals chanted,
they brought forth not demons or other Things,
they brought forth instead the ch'taren. The
ch'taren, whether exiles from the world of
dreams or even the fabled astral plane, had used
the magic of the void against itself, and had
travelled into the Prime Material by means of
their gateways. 

Bringing with them large numbers and the magics
of the Spirit, they routed the dreadlord templars
of the void to their holes in the ground, where
those that served Fire waited, and picked off the
weak among them. Humans learned of the
freedom of the Spirit, and everywhere, cast off
their chains, and drove the fiends of the Void
back once more into seclusion. 

And, thus ended the War of the Night, where
men learned that the candle of hope flickers even
in the blackest of times. 

The ch'taren settled among men, whose empire
lies shattered. The other races, long secluded by
humankind, came forth to a new Renaissance.
Some learned of the ways of the aelin, and
brought forth their own creation - the magic of
Air, which sought no rule, order, or code, merely
meaning in its own chaotic existence. 

Thus, all six of the great elemental magics were
brought to Avendar. Men, in time, sought to form
again their empire, but found the world too vast a
place - Ethron inhabitants of forest oaks, Dark
winged nefortu dangling in their dark places,
and even the alatharya of yore were returned in
diminished form. 

Still, for a time men formed a Republic on the
main continent of their home, but, in recent times,
these alliances were sundered by the raids of the
Kankoran barbarians and their allies. This has
resulted in the city states we see today -
Earandam the grand, Var Bandor, and even Ashta
Harrud, desert capitol of commerce. 

All races today find more meaning in finding their
own niche in the struggle for power, rather than a
great gasp at one empire. The Houses of Avendar
reflect this diversification of thought among the
people of Avendar. Likewise, the Scholars'
Towers, were even the mages of void and spirit
exist in an uneasy detente. 

Moreso than any time in history, the world is a
wide place, separated by long distances, with
opportunity awaiting around every street corner
in the great cities. A time, where, perhaps, the
future belongs to those who would take it, and
dare to tread the Siege Perilous - a time for
adventurers..... 

=============================================================================


<210hp 302m 206mv> 
help
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Avendar: The Crucible of Legends -- Help                         |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

You can get a help on a variety of topics to guide you through the playing
of Avendar.  Simply type help '<subject>' to gain help on a certain topic.
Here's a list of general topics you can search for help on to get you
started:

GETTING STARTED - The basics of Avendar and MUDding in general.
INFORMATION - How to get info on yourself and your surroundings.
MOVING AROUND - How to move around in the world of Avendar.
INTERACTION - How to interact with objects and items in Avendar.
COMMUNICATION - How to communicate with others in Avendar.
GROUPING - How to group together with others in Avendar.
COMBAT - How to engage (and survive!) combat in Avendar.
OVERVIEW - An overview of the basic Avendar commands (old help).

Be sure to pay attention to the "See Also" located at the bottom of many of
the helpfiles, as they often point to other useful pieces of information on
the topic you're reading on.

If you are stuck or confused and cannot find help on a certain topic, please
read 'help PRAY' for instructions on how to contact an immortal who may be
able to help you.

/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          The Deities of Avendar                                           |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Gods of the aelin     Gods of the caladaran     Gods of the ch'taren
=================     =====================     ====================
Aeolis*        NG     Alajial            NG     Calaera           NG
Alil*          CN     Chadraln           LN     Rystaia           CG
Serachel*      NE     Jalassa            LG     Vaialos           NG

Gods of the ethron    Gods of the humans        Gods of the kankoran
==================    ==================        ====================
Elar            LG    Dolgrael        LN
                      Jolinn          LG        Girikha*          CN
Lielqan         NN    Lilune          NE

Gods of the nefortu   Gods of the shuddeni      Gods of the srryn
===================   ====================      =================
Ayaunj           LN   Ashur             LE      Sitheus        LE
Bayyal           CE   Rveyelhi          LE      Fenthira       NN
Tzajai*          CN   Arkhural          CE      Sythrak*       NE

               Impartial Gods   God of the alatharya
               ==============   ====================
               Iandir      LN   Enirra            NN

Please be advised that gods that are marked with a * have helpfiles that are
either incomplete or out-of-date. They are still available; just be aware
that the documentation won't provide the best possible picture of them.

The most up-to-date resource for these deities are at our website at
http://www.avendar.net/deities.php where all profiles for all gods may be
viewed, formatted for the web.

Applications to the faiths of deities must be sent as an in-character note
to immortal explaining why your character wishes to be chosen to bear this
sign of their god's favour. Your character must have reached level 51 to be
considered. Once you have submitted this application, please reach out to the
appropriate staff member on Discord to set up a time for the in-character
follow-up. The details are in the #staff-appointments channel at
http://discord.gg/avendar

<281hp 302m 206mv> 
help offhand parry
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Offhand Parry (Skill)                                            |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Activation lag  :  1.0 rounds
Activation cost :  25 mana

Syntax: Automatic

Unimpressed by the phalanx-shields of fighters, swordmasters have mastered
the art of parrying with their secondary weapons. While slightly less
effective than parry, this skill allows a dual-wielding swordmaster to defend
with his offhand weapon; this skill is most effective against polearms, and
least against daggers and whips.


See also: PARRY, DUAL WIELD

<281hp 302m 206mv> 
help form of the reed
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Form of the Reed (Form)                                          |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Activation lag  :  1.0 rounds
Activation cost :  20 mana
Maintenance cost:  20 mana per round


Syntax: Assume 'Form of the Reed'

In the form of the reed, the swordmaster focuses all of abilities on using
his weapon to beat back his opponents attack.  Bending like a reed in the
wind, his ability to both parry and offhand parry is doubled.  However, this
level of focus means that he is then unable to attempt second, third, or
fourth attacks, and will lower the amount of damage dealt by a meditative
strike.  

See also: PARRY, OFFHAND PARRY 

<320hp 302m 206mv> 
help form of the monkey
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Form of the Monkey (Form)                                        |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Activation lag  :  1.0 rounds
Activation cost :  5 mana
Maintenance cost:  5 mana per round


Syntax: Assume 'Form of the Monkey'

A less-extreme variant of the form of the reed, form of the monkey is also
used to enhance a swordmaster's defensive capability. Less pronounced in all
regards, the swordmaster will still see a marked increase in his ability to
parry and offhand parry, and he will be unable to attempt to make a fourth
attack in a combat round.


See also: PARRY, OFFHAND PARRY, FORM OF THE REED

<320hp 302m 206mv> 


<320hp 302m 206mv> 
help form of the mongoose
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Form of the Mongoose (Form)                                      |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Activation lag  :  1.0 rounds
Activation cost :  20 mana
Maintenance cost:  20 mana per round


Syntax: Assume 'Form of the Mongoose'

Imitating the exotic mongoose, this notoriously stylish form allows a
swordmaster to strike successively in combat, for each blow he attempts to
land. These attacks may miss or be blocked as with any other.

<320hp 302m 206mv> 
A Path Through the Foothills
  A small path formed by the recent passing of wagon wheels leads through
the foothills, sinking deeply into the earth of the foothills.  To the
north, the trail bends toward a group of foothills rising above the others. 
To the west, the trail returns toward the Brintor Road.  

[Exits: north west]

n
<320hp 302m 206mv> A Path to a Hill
  To the north, the path veers sharply toward a cluster of low foothills. 
An opening in the face of the nearest hill leads into a cavern, and to the
south, the lower foothills spread vastly.  Far in the distance, the peaks of
the Brintor Mountains tower above the horizon, a grand spectacle in the
background.  

[Exits: north south]

n
The Mouth of the Cave
  A gap in the face of the hill opens into a large cave.  The walls are
slick with condensed moisture and growths of fungus.  There is a musty air
to the natural passage that leads north.  Many footprints mar the soft dirt
of the cave floor, packing it into a regular path in some areas.  

[Exits: north south]
A black cave bat clings to the wall.

<320hp 302m 204mv> 
n
A Damp Cave
  The damp cave continues, leading into the darkness to the north, and
toward the light of a cave mouth to the south.  The cave walls drip with
moisture, and subterranean fungi grow in colored patches.  The dirt of the
floor is packed by many footprints.  

[Exits: north south]
A black cave bat clings to the wall.
A red cave beetle flexes its mandibles threateningly.

<320hp 302m 201mv> 
n
The Mining Camp
  This stretch of cave is crowded with mining equipment, bedrolls for
several men, provisions, and various clutter.  Apparently this is the
temporary camp of a mining party.  Further evidence lies in a mine shaft
sunk into the west wall of the cave, and three mine carts partially filled
with ore.  The main cave continues north and south.  

[Exits: north south west]
     A mining cart carries recently mined ore.
A burly miner, hardened by years of work, digs tirelessly at the cave wall.

help fast healing
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Fast Healing (Skill)                                             |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Activation lag  :  0.0 rounds
Activation cost :  0 mana

Syntax: Automatic

Fast healing is a skill taught by most guilds, that their students might apply
their knowledge to quicker recovery of bodily injuries, increasing the rate at
which they gain hit points.


See also: HIT POINTS

<195hp 291m 206mv> 
help hit points
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Hit Points                                                       |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Your characters hit points are a measure of your ability
to sustain physical injuries to your body. If your hit points
ever drop to 0, you become incapacitated and begin to
slowly bleed to death. If your hp drops below -10, your character
will die. (see help DEATH) As your level increases, so 
too will your hit points. How much your hit points increase
is a function of your character's constitution and class.

<223hp 302m 206mv> 
help armor
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Armor (Spell)                                                    |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Activation lag  :  1.0 rounds

The armor spell grants a slight bonus to the target's armor class, making
them marginally harder to hit.  

<223hp 302m 206mv> 
help armor class
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Armor Class                                                      |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Your armor class, visible with the 'SCORE' command, tells you how
well-armored you are against the physical and magical dangers of the world. 
It is a combination of natural intelligence, the protection offered by worn
items, and magical enchantments or enhancements.  Your AC is also affected
by your body position--sleeping characters have worse AC.  

The lower (more negative) your AC number is, the more effective your armor
will be at reducing damage, as a percentage value, with increasing returns
for lower values.  Against lesser opponents it may help to avoid being hit
altogether.  On the other hand, having an AC higher than zero will increase
vulnerability to damage.  

See also: SAVES and SCORE 

<223hp 302m 206mv> 
help saves
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Saving Throws and Resistances                                    |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Two of your primary defenses against magical attacks and effects lay in two
areas: saving throws, and resists.

Saving throws (or 'saves') represent your generic resistance to all types
of magic.  In general, whenever you are the target of a spell or other
magical malediction, your saves are factored in when determining whether
you resist the effects.  Much like armor class, negative saves are better.

Resists (and vulnerabilities, which are essentially negative resists) are
more focused in nature, and only help against a specified type of magic or
damage.  When determining whether you resist a spirit scholar's 'manabarbs'
spell, for example, both your saves and your 'mental' resistance are taken
into account.  Resists also subtract, as a percentage, from the amount of
damage you take from attacks of that type.

See also: SAVES2

<223hp 302m 206mv> 
help saves2
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          All About Saves, Resistance, and Damage Reduction                |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

  Example A: a fireball is cast on you, doing 100 fire damage.
  Example B: a flaming sword hits you, doing 100 fire damage.
  Example C: a magic missile spell is cast at you, doing 100 "other" damage

Saves
Saves represent magical resistance in general, and are shown in SCORE. They 
apply to all damage types. However, they also only apply to spells. In the 
case of (most) damage spells, they halve the damage (there are notable 
exceptions, like disintegration). To use the examples from above:
  
Example A: if you save against the fireball, you take 50 fire damage instead 
           of 100
Example B: this is a magic damtype, but not actually a spell. You get no save 
           chance, and take the full 100 damage
Example C: if you save against the magic missile, you take 50 other damage
           instead of 100


Damage Reduction
Damage reduction isn't a specific stat, but rather a concept not explicitly 
shown in score. Generally speaking, it represents a percentage by which 
damage is reduced (a few things, like durability and fugue, reduce instead 
by subtraction, making them more useful against lower damages and less 
against higher damages). It can apply to all or almost all damage (like with
sanctuary), or just to certain types. So in the examples below, assume you 
have 20% fire damage reduction from firekin:

Example A: the 20% reduction means you take 80 fire damage instead of 100.
           If you also saved, you'd take 40 damage. However, the damage 
           reduction does not help you save.
Example B: as with (A), you'd take 80 fire damage. Since damage reduction 
           doesn't care whether the source is a spell or not, it applies 
           here, while saves still do not.
Example C: your damage reduction is against fire, so you still take the full 
           100 damage.
  
  
Resistance
Resistance is the cream of the crop, acting as a sort of combination of 
saves AND damage reduction. However, unlike normal saves, the saves implied 
by resistance ONLY affect the specified damtype. The number of saves equals 
the amount of resistance, so for example if you cast ward of frost and gain
25 resistance to fire, you've just given yourself an additional 25 saves 
when saving against fire type spells, as well as 25% damage reduction. 25 
saves is a lot, so you will save very often against fire. Note that this 
doesn't mean fire-sphere spells necessarily,  it means fire-type spells. To
be sure, most fire-sphere spells are also fire-type, but to draw an example
from another sphere: searing light is spirit-sphere, but of type light, while
spiritwrack is also of spirit-sphere, but of type holy.
  
Anyway, let's go back to our example, assuming you've put up that ward of 
frost and gotten 25 resistance to fire as a result:

Example A: the bonus 25 saves from the resistance means you will probably 
           save, bringing the 100 damage to 50. But the 25 damage 
           reduction from the spell drops it further to 37.5.
Example B: the saves aspect does not help you since you cannot save melee 
           strikes. The 25 damage reduction still helps, bringing the 100
           damage down to 75.
Example C: the damtypes don't match up (fire vs other), so the spell doesn't
           help you at all. The 100 damage stands at 100, unless your normal
           saves manage to halve it.

<223hp 302m 206mv> 
help score
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Score                                                            |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

The SCORE command shows you a variety of helpful statistics. Moving in roughly
clockwise fashion around the readout:

Your primary attributes appear on the upper-left side in the form of current
value(true value); for example, "Wis: 18(17)" would mean that your natural
Wisdom score is 17, but modified to 18 by some ability or equipment.

To the right is a block that displays various vital statistics, including your
race, class, gender, age (including age category), and the number of hours you
have logged playing as this character. Just a little bit further below shows
your hit points, experience, experience to level, and exploration points.

Below that is a block detailing the number of practices, trains, cash on hand,
and general details about the amounts and weights of the totality of the items
you are carrying. It also displays your alignment.

Underneath that is a large box, detailing your birthday, encumbrance, creation
traits, and how hungry you are. Further below that box might appear your
entire affects list, if you have opted to show them in the score via the SHOW
command; this can get very cluttered, but the option is available.

Finally, just below your primary attributes is a box displaying your armour
class.

Particularly long-term players might prefer the OLDSCORE command, which
displays much the same information, in a more antique readout; this is not
recommended, but remains available for people who choose to use it.

See also: STATS, AGE, EP, HITROLL, DAMROLL, SAVES, ENCUMBRANCE, etc.

<223hp 302m 206mv> 
help states
No help on that word.

<223hp 302m 206mv> 
help stats
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Statistics                                                       |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Your statistics (stats) determine the degree of your character's physical and
mental aptitudes.  Stats range from 3-25, and all characters will have -5 to
their lineage maximums at level 1, then gain 1 to all stats every 10 levels
until 50. Statistics can be temporarily improved by items or affects, and
bonuses to your stats will offset debuffs. The specific effects of each stat
are listed in their helpfiles; your stats have no impact on the effectiveness
of your skills, HP/MP/MV gain, etc, only what is listed.

The following is a table of the playable lineages and their lineage maximums:

            Str     Int     Wis     Dex     Con     Chr
            ---     ---     ---     ---     ---     ---  
Aelin        17      23      17      23      17      25
Alatharya    25      17      17      17      23      23
Caladaran    17      23      25      17      23      17
Chaja        25      17      17      23      23      17
Ch'taren     17      25      23      17      17      23
Ethron       23      17      25      17      17      23
Human*       20      20      20      20      20      20
Nefortu      17      23      17      25      23      17
Shuddeni     17      25      23      17      17      23
Srryn        23      17      17      23      25      17

* Humans have 3 attribute points in chargen to distribute as they please.

See also: STRENGTH, INTELLIGENCE, WISDOM, DEXTERITY, CONSTITUTION, CHARISMA

<223hp 302m 206mv> 
help strength
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          STRENGTH                                                         |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Modifies the character's damage roll.  While this is typically a bonus,
it is a penalty at particularly low values.  

Adds a bonus to the character's carry capacity.  

Determines the maximum weight a character's mainhand weapon can be.  

<257hp 302m 206mv> 
help intelligence
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          INTELLIGENCE                                                     |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Modifies the character's armor class.  While this is typically a bonus,
it is a penalty at particularly low values.  

Reduces all mana costs.  

Increases passive mana point recovery.  

<257hp 302m 206mv> 
help wisdom
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          WISDOM                                                           |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Modifies the character's saves.  While this is typically a bonus, it is a
penalty at particularly low values.  

Adds a bonus to all forms of active mana recovery, such as cantrips or
Brawler's Renewal.  

Grants a bonus to healing effects.  

<257hp 302m 206mv> 
help dexterity
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          DEXTERITY                                                        |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Modifies the character's hit roll.  While this is typically a bonus, it
is a penalty at particularly low levels.  

Reduces all move costs.  

Increases the range of weight a character's offhand weapon can be when dual
wielding.  

<257hp 302m 206mv> 
help constitution
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          CONSTITUTION                                                     |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Grants a chance to resist poisons.

Increases passive hit point recovery.

Increases the character's maximum death total.

<257hp 302m 206mv> 
help charisma
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          CHARISMA                                                         |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Modifies the character's prices when purchasing from shops.  While this
is typically a bonus, it is a penalty at particularly low levels.  

Increases the character's chances of a successful reward with sacrifice.  

Increase the caster level of spells cast.

<257hp 302m 206mv> 
help age
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Age (Spell)                                                      |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Activation lag  :  0.0 rounds
Activation cost :  0 mana

During your time in Avendar, your character will age.  This aging process is
correlated to the time your character has been in existence.  On average,
characters will live about six and a half months, real time.  As you age, you
will experience various benefits or penalties for your age.

Different races age at different rates, hence a caladaran will start their
character older than a human, and a ch'taren will start significantly younger
than a human.  Regardless, all characters start out in what humans would term
as a young adult, mentally, physically, and socially.  If you are unsure how
to play your character's age, simply refer to the term in the brackets beside
it (ie, Youthful, mature, etc) for guidance.

The various categories are:

Youthful    : All characters create at this age.
Mature      : +2 Strength, +1 Dexterity
Middle-Aged : +1 Intelligence, +1 Wisdom
Senior      : -1 Strength, +1 Intelligence, +2 Wisdom, -1 Dexterity
Old         : -2 Strength, +1 Intelligence, +2 Wisdom, -2 Dexterity,
              -1 Constitution, -3 resistance to bash damage.
Elderly     : -2 Strength, +1 Intelligence, +2 Wisdom, -2 Dexterity,
              -1 Constitution, -6 resistance to bash damage (total).
Ancient     : -4 Strength, +1 Wisdom, -2 Dexterity, -2 Constitution,
              -9 resistance to bash damage (total).

Should one somehow become older than this, there may be further penalties.

<257hp 302m 206mv> 
help ep
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Exploration Points                                               |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

In order to attain the next level, you must do more than acquire the
requisite experience points. You must also obtain the requisite 
exploration points (ep for short).
  
A character acquires exploration points by visiting rooms. Ep are
only gained on the first visit to a room. Some rooms or areas are
more dangerous than others, and will give more ep when visited. 
In brief mode, rooms do not count as being visited. A total of
4500 EP is required in order to achieve level 51.
  
-----
  
Syntax: EP 
  
The 'EP' command toggles notification of exploration points on 
and off.

to the natural passage that leads north.  Many footprints mar the soft dirt
of the cave floor, packing it into a regular path in some areas.

south, the lower foothills spread vastly.  Far in the distance, the peaks of
the Brintor Mountains tower above the horizon, a grand spectacle in the
background.

<285hp 248m 196mv> 
A Path Through the Foothills
  A small path formed by the recent passing of wagon wheels leads through
the foothills, sinking deeply into the earth of the foothills.  To the
north, the trail bends toward a group of foothills rising above the others. 
To the west, the trail returns toward the Brintor Road.  

[Exits: north west]

whe

Alas, you cannot go that way.

<358hp 302m 206mv> 
A Path Through the Foothills
  A small path formed by the recent passing of wagon wheels leads through
the foothills, sinking deeply into the earth of the foothills.  To the
north, the trail bends toward a group of foothills rising above the others. 
To the west, the trail returns toward the Brintor Road.  

[Exits: north west]

<358hp 302m 206mv> 
n
A Path to a Hill
  To the north, the path veers sharply toward a cluster of low foothills. 
An opening in the face of the nearest hill leads into a cavern, and to the
south, the lower foothills spread vastly.  Far in the distance, the peaks of
the Brintor Mountains tower above the horizon, a grand spectacle in the
background.  

[Exits: north south]

n
<358hp 302m 205mv> 
The Mouth of the Cave
  A gap in the face of the hill opens into a large cave.  The walls are
slick with condensed moisture and growths of fungus.  There is a musty air
to the natural passage that leads north.  Many footprints mar the soft dirt
of the cave floor, packing it into a regular path in some areas.  

[Exits: north south]
A black cave bat clings to the wall.

<358hp 302m 204mv> 
n
A Damp Cave
  The damp cave continues, leading into the darkness to the north, and
toward the light of a cave mouth to the south.  The cave walls drip with
moisture, and subterranean fungi grow in colored patches.  The dirt of the
floor is packed by many footprints.  

[Exits: north south]
A red cave beetle flexes its mandibles threateningly.
A black cave bat clings to the wall.

<358hp 302m 201mv> 
n
The Mining Camp
  This stretch of cave is crowded with mining equipment, bedrolls for
several men, provisions, and various clutter.  Apparently this is the
temporary camp of a mining party.  Further evidence lies in a mine shaft
sunk into the west wall of the cave, and three mine carts partially filled
with ore.  The main cave continues north and south.  

[Exits: north south west]
     A mining cart carries recently mined ore.
A burly miner, hardened by years of work, digs tirelessly at the cave wall.

<358hp 302m 189mv> 
The Brintor Road
  The wide dirt way known as the Brintor Road leads north out of the Arien
Plains, now giving way to the rolling foothills of the Brintor Mountains. 
The low scrub bushes that populated the praries are now interspersed with
struggling evergreens and patches of rough grass.  Far to the north you can
make out the outline of the Brintor peaks against the sky.  A small side
path, formed by the recent passing of wagon wheels, leads toward a small
cluster of hills to the east.  

[Exits: north east south]

The Arien Road
  Outside the western gates of Earendam, the Arien Road stretches into the
distance to the west.  Leading through the Plains of Arien to Var Bandor,
the broad strip of stones accomodates a great number of caravans, travelers
and merchants.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<358hp 302m 179mv> 
The West Gate of Earendam
  Earendam's west gates are made of sturdy iron, built between two tall
stone pillars.  Reinforcing these gates are several stout bars of iron,
treated to preserve them from wear.  Outside the gates, the Arien Road heads
west, cutting across the plains which give it its namesake.  Inside, the
Arien Plaza opens, marking the beginning of Earendam proper.  

[Exits: east west]
An Earendam gate guard stands at attention.
An Earendam gate guard stands at attention.

<358hp 302m 178mv> 
e
The Western Arien Plaza
  The Arien Plaza comes to an end here as it approaches the western gate of
Earendam.  Travelers and merchants head out through this gate onto the
Arien road, bringing goods to and from the lands to the west.  Set in the
northwestern portion of the city, this plaza is a square ringed on all
sides by the buildings and walls of New Earendam.  Paved with cobblestones
long worn smooth by the feet of travelers entering the city from the Arien
road, the center of the square lies eastward, where an ornate fountain
serves as a resting place for the main body of the populace in the immediate
area.  Shops line the northern edge of the square, while southward the plaza
eventually terminates in a stone wall.  

[Exits: north east south west]
A hulking alatharya porter carries goods for a merchant.
A merchant from Var Bandor strolls through the plaza.

<358hp 302m 177mv> 
n
The Northwestern Arien Plaza
  The northwestern corner of the Arien Plaza bustles with activity as it
approaches the city walls of Earendam to the west.  Travelers and merchants
wander through the area, mainly heading to, or coming from the west gate of
Earendam to the south.  The edge of the plaza lines a row of shops to the
east, but comes to an end here, where a large inn sits in the crook between
the city wall and the shops to the east, and is marked by the sign of a
flagon and bedroll.  

[Exits: north east south]
A merchant's bodyguard scans the crowd, watchful of his charge.
A merchant of Earendam mills about the plaza.

n
n
<358hp 302m 176mv> 
Anteroom of the Arien Way
  This small hallway serves as the anteroom for the Arien Way, a popular
tavern in this part of Earendam.  Covered in panelled pine, the walls of the
hallway narrow in a doorway to the north, leading to the interior of the
tavern.  Covering the floor of the anteroom is a tiled mosaic, depicting the
traditional sign of a tavern, made using colored stones from the Brintors. 
The streets of Arien plaza are to the south.  

[Exits: north south]
A grizzled ethron is here, eyeing people as they enter.

w
<358hp 302m 175mv> 
The Arien Way
  The Arien Way tavern's common room is west of here, opening past an
arched entryway.  The end of a wood-panelled hallway, this area connects to
a small anteroom to the south, and a stairwell leads north to the rooms above. 

[Exits: north south west]

s
s
<358hp 302m 174mv> 
s
The Common Room of the Arien Way
  The common room of the Arien Way is a large square chamber, panelled with
planks of scented pines.  Filled with tables and the smoke of the torches
which illuminate the chamber, this room is a common gathering place for the
merchants who frequent the Arien Plaza.  The room's decor seems to be a cut
above the typical tavern, with the occasional painting adorning the walls,
and a simple tile mosaic covering the floor.  An exit lies to a hallway to
the east, and the bar is further west of here.  

[Exits: east south west]

<50hp 271m 190mv> 
help hawk
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Form of the Hawk (Form)                                          |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Activation lag  :  1.0 rounds
Activation cost :  20 mana
Maintenance cost:  20 mana per round


Syntax: Assume 'Form of the Hawk'

Dancing through the opponents blows like a nimble hawk, a swordmaster in the
form of the hawk finds that their ability to protect himself increases: their
dexterity increases and they gains a bonus to his armour class proportional to
their level. In this form, there is also a chance that they will evade
attempts to trip them, legsweep them, cross, ensnare, or surprise attack them,
punishing those who try with a full round of attacks.


See also: ARMOR CLASS, TRIP, SWEEP, LEGSWEEP, other listed skills

<144hp 302m 206mv> 
help monkey
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Form of the Monkey (Form)                                        |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Activation lag  :  1.0 rounds
Activation cost :  5 mana
Maintenance cost:  5 mana per round


Syntax: Assume 'Form of the Monkey'

A less-extreme variant of the form of the reed, form of the monkey is also
used to enhance a swordmaster's defensive capability. Less pronounced in all
regards, the swordmaster will still see a marked increase in his ability to
parry and offhand parry, and he will be unable to attempt to make a fourth
attack in a combat round.


See also: PARRY, OFFHAND PARRY, FORM OF THE REED

<358hp 302m 206mv> 
The Common Room of the Arien Way
  The common room of the Arien Way is a large square chamber, panelled with
planks of scented pines.  Filled with tables and the smoke of the torches
which illuminate the chamber, this room is a common gathering place for the
merchants who frequent the Arien Plaza.  The room's decor seems to be a cut
above the typical tavern, with the occasional painting adorning the walls,
and a simple tile mosaic covering the floor.  The common room continues in
all directions save east.  

[Exits: north south west]
A portly merchant sits here, having dinner.

<358hp 302m 206mv> 
help command
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Command Control Spiritvision                                     |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Syntax: Command
        Command Show
        Command <Action>

        Control
        Control Show
        Control <Target PC>

        Spiritvision

Void scholars can command a victim possessed by an unclean spirit to
perform certain actions, should the target's will prove weaker than
their demonic infiltration.  The target is manipulated through the
commands 'command', 'control', and 'spiritvision'.

Command: 'command show' or 'command' by itself will inform the Void
Scholar who the current focus of their orders is.  When given an
argument ('command <action>'), this command attempts to force the
victim to perform the desired action.  If the target does not save,
he or she will carry out the will of the void scholar.  Note that
each order hastens the eventual escape of the victim.

Examples:
>command show
You are currently controlling Raestral.

>command grin
Raestral does as you bid.
Raestral grins broadly.

Control: 'control show' or 'control' by itself will display to the
Void Scholar a list of people they have managed to possess with
unclean spirits, as well as which one they are currently commanding.
When given an argument ('control <Target PC>'), this command will
switch the focus of the Void Scholar's orders.

Examples:
You are currently controlling Raestral.
Your will has been forced upon the following:
Raestral
Jolinn
Iandir

>control Jolinn
You shift your control to Jolinn.

>command
You are currently controlling Jolinn.

Spiritvision: A Void Scholar who has managed to possess another
person with an unclean spirit can manipulate that spirit's senses
through the 'spiritvision' command.  This will grant the scholar a
brief glance at the world around the spirit.  Since the sense comes
from the spirit, rather than the victim, the victim need not be able
to see or even awake for the command to work. However, because the
spirit must extend a good portion of its being back to the scholar
to transmit the glimpse, use of this command will greatly hasten the
eventual escape of the victim.

Note that while the victim must be present for the initial
possession, he or she may be controlled through the use of these
three commands from anywhere in the Prime Material.

Note also that while there is much freedom to one's commands, OOC
abuse of this power will not be tolerated.  Attempts to make the
victim change their password or prompt, modify their description or
background, or other such abuses are against the rules.

<358hp 302m 206mv> 


<358hp 302m 206mv> 
help commands
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          AREAS COMMANDS WORTH TIME                                        |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

Syntax: areas Syntax: commands Syntax: score Syntax: time Syntax: weather
Syntax: time system

AREAS shows you a list of areas in the game, including suggested level ranges
for each.

COMMANDS shows you all the commands in the game.

TIME shows the Avendarian time.

TIME SYSTEM shows the system time, as well as when the mud last started,
and the current local time for the host computer.

WEATHER shows the current game weather.

The WORTH command will bring up a quick spread of useful information,
detailing such things as the amount of gold you have, how much xp/ep
needed to reach the next level, and the number of arrows in your
possession.  Spellcasters should note that when they are encumbered,
they will be able to see it through the worth command.

<358hp 302m 206mv>

  The common room of the Arien Way is a large square chamber, panelled with
planks of scented pines.  Filled with tables and the smoke of the torches
which illuminate the chamber, this room is a common gathering place for the
merchants who frequent the Arien Plaza.  The room's decor seems to be a cut
above the typical tavern, with the occasional painting adorning the walls,
and a simple tile mosaic covering the floor.  The common room continues in
all directions save east.

  The common room of the Arien Way is a large square chamber, panelled with

The Common Room of the Arien Way
  The common room of the Arien Way is a large square chamber, panelled with
planks of scented pines.  Filled with tables and the smoke of the torches
which illuminate the chamber, this room is a common gathering place for the
merchants who frequent the Arien Plaza.  The room's decor seems to be a cut

<358hp 302m 204mv> 
w
The Bar of the Arien Way
  Located on the western side of the common room of the Arien Way, this bar
comes to an end here, continuing further north as it hugs the wall.  This
part of the tavern is rather smoke-filled, as it approaches the kitchens,
which lie past a wooden set of double doors to the west.  The common room
opens to the east of here.  

[Exits: north east west]

<358hp 302m 203mv> 
w
You gained 1 exploration point and 50 experience points!
Kitchens
  These chambers house the kitchens of the Arien Way.  Set against the
western wall are a hearth and a wood oven, which fill the room with smoke
despite the small chimney which is built into the hearth.  Also featured
prominently are cutting boards and racks of spices, all bearing the marks of
much use.  

[Exits: east]
The tavern's cook works here.

n
<358hp 302m 199mv> The Common Room of the Arien Way
  The common room of the Arien Way is a large square chamber, panelled with
planks of scented pines.  Filled with tables and the smoke of the torches
which illuminate the chamber, this room is a common gathering place for the
merchants who frequent the Arien Plaza.  The room's decor seems to be a cut
above the typical tavern, with the occasional painting adorning the walls,
and a simple tile mosaic covering the floor.  The common room continues in
all directions save east.  

[Exits: north south west]
A portly merchant sits here, having dinner.

and a simple tile mosaic covering the floor.  An exit lies to a hallway to
the east, and the bar is further west of here.

The Common Room of the Arien Way
  The common room of the Arien Way is a large square chamber, panelled with
planks of scented pines.  Filled with tables and the smoke of the torches
which illuminate the chamber, this room is a common gathering place for the
merchants who frequent the Arien Plaza.  The room's decor seems to be a cut

and a simple tile mosaic covering the floor.  The common room continues

<358hp 302m 194mv> 
w
The Bar of the Arien Way
  Located on the western side of the common room of the Arien Way, this bar
comes to an end here, continuing further north as it hugs the wall.  This
part of the tavern is rather smoke-filled, as it approaches the kitchens,
which lie past a wooden set of double doors to the west.  The common room
opens to the east of here.  

[Exits: north east west]

<358hp 302m 193mv> 
w
Kitchens
  These chambers house the kitchens of the Arien Way.  Set against the
western wall are a hearth and a wood oven, which fill the room with smoke
despite the small chimney which is built into the hearth.  Also featured
prominently are cutting boards and racks of spices, all bearing the marks of
much use.  

[Exits: east]
The tavern's cook works here.

<358hp 302m 187mv> 
The Arien Way
  The Arien Way tavern's common room is west of here, opening past an
arched entryway.  The end of a wood-panelled hallway, this area connects to
a small anteroom to the south, and a stairwell leads north to the rooms above. 

[Exits: north south west]

s
<358hp 302m 186mv> 
s
Anteroom of the Arien Way
  This small hallway serves as the anteroom for the Arien Way, a popular
tavern in this part of Earendam.  Covered in panelled pine, the walls of the
hallway narrow in a doorway to the north, leading to the interior of the
tavern.  Covering the floor of the anteroom is a tiled mosaic, depicting the
traditional sign of a tavern, made using colored stones from the Brintors. 
The streets of Arien plaza are to the south.  

[Exits: north south]
A grizzled ethron is here, eyeing people as they enter.

<358hp 302m 185mv> 
The Northwestern Arien Plaza
  The northwestern corner of the Arien Plaza bustles with activity as it
approaches the city walls of Earendam to the west.  Travelers and merchants
wander through the area, mainly heading to, or coming from the west gate of
Earendam to the south.  The edge of the plaza lines a row of shops to the
east, but comes to an end here, where a large inn sits in the crook between
the city wall and the shops to the east, and is marked by the sign of a
flagon and bedroll.  

[Exits: north east south]
A merchant's bodyguard scans the crowd, watchful of his charge.
A merchant of Earendam mills about the plaza.

<358hp 302m 184mv> 
s
The Western Arien Plaza
  The Arien Plaza comes to an end here as it approaches the western gate of
Earendam.  Travelers and merchants head out through this gate onto the
Arien road, bringing goods to and from the lands to the west.  Set in the
northwestern portion of the city, this plaza is a square ringed on all
sides by the buildings and walls of New Earendam.  Paved with cobblestones
long worn smooth by the feet of travelers entering the city from the Arien
road, the center of the square lies eastward, where an ornate fountain
serves as a resting place for the main body of the populace in the immediate
area.  Shops line the northern edge of the square, while southward the plaza
eventually terminates in a stone wall.  

[Exits: north east south west]
A hulking alatharya porter carries goods for a merchant.
A merchant from Var Bandor strolls through the plaza.

w
<358hp 302m 183mv> 
The West Gate of Earendam
  Earendam's west gates are made of sturdy iron, built between two tall
stone pillars.  Reinforcing these gates are several stout bars of iron,
treated to preserve them from wear.  Outside the gates, the Arien Road heads
west, cutting across the plains which give it its namesake.  Inside, the
Arien Plaza opens, marking the beginning of Earendam proper.  

[Exits: east west]
An Earendam gate guard stands at attention.
An Earendam gate guard stands at attention.

distance to the west.  Leading through the Plains of Arien to Var Bandor,
the broad strip of stones accomodates a great number of caravans, travelers
and merchants.

<358hp 302m 205mv> 
n
The Arien Plains
  The flat Arien Plains stretch before you, gray, vast and unchanging. 
Small shrubs grow here and there, surrounded by patches of dry grass, but
for the most part the Plains are unvegetated.  To the south, the Arien Road
travels between Var Bandor and Earendam.  

[Exits: east south west]

w
The Arien Plains
  The flat Arien Plains stretch before you, gray, vast and unchanging. 
Small shrubs grow here and there, surrounded by patches of dry grass, but
for the most part the Plains are unvegetated.  To the south, the Arien Road
travels between Var Bandor and Earendam.  To the north stands the pale
sandstone of the tower of Aramril, home of the Champions of Avendar.

<358hp 302m 203mv> 
n
n
You gained 2 exploration points and 100 experience points!
A Sandstone Gatehouse
  This is the gatehouse of the Tower of Aramril.  It passes several paces
through the width of the massive outer curtain wall.  The enormous blocks of
sandstone, ancient and time-weathered, are fitted together without any sign
of mortar.  The walls curve upwards in a smooth barrel vault.  From the
center of the roof hangs a wrought silver lamp.  The spiked bottom of a
heavy portcullis of gilded steel is visible, kept open except in the most
dire of emergencies.  To the south, the Arien Plains stretch, vast, grey,
and dusty.  A flagstone path leads north out of the gatehouse, through lush
grounds, to the Tower actual.  

[Exits: north south]
A friendly caladaran woman maintains a patient vigil.

<358hp 302m 202mv> 
You gained 2 exploration points and 100 experience points!
A Flagstone Pathway
  A small flagstone pathway leads from the gatehouse set in the thick outer
wall to the south, running northwards.  It arrives at the white marble
threshold of the sandstone Tower of Aramril which stretches high into the
air.  Perfectly round, the tower is surrounded by a shorter, though still
quite tall, outer curtain wall of pale stone.  In the space between lavish
gardens have been planted, a profusion of flowering plants growing with
almost unnatural fertility.  A meandering path of stepping stones makes its
way through the grounds to the east and west.  

[Exits: north east south west]
     A carved stone sculpture of a human woman stands to the east.
     An aging stone statue of a human man looms west of the path.

<358hp 302m 201mv> 
s
A Sandstone Gatehouse
  This is the gatehouse of the Tower of Aramril.  It passes several paces
through the width of the massive outer curtain wall.  The enormous blocks of
sandstone, ancient and time-weathered, are fitted together without any sign
of mortar.  The walls curve upwards in a smooth barrel vault.  From the
center of the roof hangs a wrought silver lamp.  The spiked bottom of a
heavy portcullis of gilded steel is visible, kept open except in the most
dire of emergencies.  To the south, the Arien Plains stretch, vast, grey,
and dusty.  A flagstone path leads north out of the gatehouse, through lush
grounds, to the Tower actual.  

[Exits: north south]
A friendly caladaran woman maintains a patient vigil.
Lacheda folds her hands and says, 'Welcome to the Tower of Aramril!  The gardens are open to all.'

travels between Var Bandor and Earendam.  To the north stands the pale
sandstone of the tower of Aramril, home of the Champions of Avendar.

w
The Brintor Road
  The wide dirt way known as the Brintor Road leads north through the Arien
Plains, gashing a brown line through the monotony of the prairies.  Deep ruts
carved into the road indicate the passing of carts and caravans seeking
trade with the people of the Brintor Mountains to the north.  South, the
Arien Road leads between Earendam and Var Bandor.  

[Exits: north east south west]
A dusty brown goose waddles about nervously.

n
The Brintor Road
  The wide dirt way known as the Brintor Road leads north out of the Arien
Plains, now giving way to the rolling foothills of the Brintor Mountains. 
The low scrub bushes that populated the praries are now interspersed with
struggling evergreens and patches of rough grass.  Far to the north you can
make out the outline of the Brintor peaks against the sky.

<358hp 302m 178mv> 
The Brintor Road
  The wide dirt way known as the Brintor Road leads north out of the Arien
Plains, now giving way to the rolling foothills of the Brintor Mountains. 
The low scrub bushes that populated the praries are now interspersed with
struggling evergreens and patches of rough grass.  Far to the north you can
make out the outline of the Brintor peaks against the sky.  A small side
path, formed by the recent passing of wagon wheels, leads toward a small
cluster of hills to the east.  

[Exits: north east south]

e
<358hp 302m 177mv> 
A Path Through the Foothills
  A small path formed by the recent passing of wagon wheels leads through
the foothills, sinking deeply into the earth of the foothills.  To the
north, the trail bends toward a group of foothills rising above the others. 
To the west, the trail returns toward the Brintor Road.  

[Exits: east west]

<358hp 302m 175mv> 
n
A Path to a Hill
  To the north, the path veers sharply toward a cluster of low foothills. 
An opening in the face of the nearest hill leads into a cavern, and to the
south, the lower foothills spread vastly.  Far in the distance, the peaks of
the Brintor Mountains tower above the horizon, a grand spectacle in the
background.  

[Exits: north south]

<358hp 302m 174mv> 
The Mouth of the Cave
  A gap in the face of the hill opens into a large cave.  The walls are
slick with condensed moisture and growths of fungus.  There is a musty air
to the natural passage that leads north.  Many footprints mar the soft dirt
of the cave floor, packing it into a regular path in some areas.  

[Exits: north south]
A black cave bat clings to the wall.

<358hp 302m 173mv> 
n
A Damp Cave
  The damp cave continues, leading into the darkness to the north, and
toward the light of a cave mouth to the south.  The cave walls drip with
moisture, and subterranean fungi grow in colored patches.  The dirt of the
floor is packed by many footprints.  

[Exits: north south]
A black cave bat clings to the wall.

<358hp 302m 170mv> 
n
The Mining Camp
  This stretch of cave is crowded with mining equipment, bedrolls for
several men, provisions, and various clutter.  Apparently this is the
temporary camp of a mining party.  Further evidence lies in a mine shaft
sunk into the west wall of the cave, and three mine carts partially filled
with ore.  The main cave continues north and south.

  This stretch of cave is crowded with mining equipment, bedrolls for
several men, provisions, and various clutter.  Apparently this is the
temporary camp of a mining party.  Further evidence lies in mine shafts sunk
into the east and west walls of the cave, and mine carts partially filled
with ore.  The main cave continues north and south.  

[Exits: north east south west]
     A mining cart carries recently mined ore.
A burly miner, hardened by years of work, digs tirelessly at the cave wall.

A Damp Cave
  The damp cave continues, leading into the darkness to the north, and
toward the light of a cave mouth to the south.  The cave walls drip with
moisture, and subterranean fungi grow in colored patches.  The dirt of the
floor is packed by many footprints.

<207hp 239m 202mv> 
The Mouth of the Cave
  A gap in the face of the hill opens into a large cave.  The walls are
slick with condensed moisture and growths of fungus.  There is a musty air
to the natural passage that leads north.  Many footprints mar the soft dirt
of the cave floor, packing it into a regular path in some areas.

  To the north, the path veers sharply toward a cluster of low foothills.

south, the lower foothills spread vastly.  Far in the distance, the peaks of
the Brintor Mountains tower above the horizon, a grand spectacle in the
background.

A Mine Shaft
  The small mine shaft tapers to an end at this point.  Several mining
tools lean against the stone wall, and loose ore, still to be removed,
scatters the ground.  Unhewn granite prevents further passage into the
mountain, and the mine shaft returns toward camp to the east.

A Damp Cave
  The damp cave continues, leading into the darkness to the north, and
toward the light of a cave mouth to the south.  The cave walls drip with
moisture, and subterranean fungi grow in colored patches.  The dirt of the
floor is packed by many footprints.  

[Exits: north south]

<385hp 327m 207mv> 
The Mouth of the Cave
  A gap in the face of the hill opens into a large cave.  The walls are
slick with condensed moisture and growths of fungus.  There is a musty air
to the natural passage that leads north.  Many footprints mar the soft dirt
of the cave floor, packing it into a regular path in some areas.  

[Exits: north south]
A black cave bat clings to the wall.

<390hp 334m 219mv> 
A Path to a Hill
  To the north, the path veers sharply toward a cluster of low foothills. 
An opening in the face of the nearest hill leads into a cavern, and to the
south, the lower foothills spread vastly.  Far in the distance, the peaks of
the Brintor Mountains tower above the horizon, a grand spectacle in the
background.  

[Exits: north south]

<390hp 334m 218mv>

the foothills, sinking deeply into the earth of the foothills.  To the
north, the trail bends toward a group of foothills rising above the others. 
To the west, the trail returns toward the Brintor Road.

<390hp 334m 213mv> 
help
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Avendar: The Crucible of Legends -- Help                         |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

You can get a help on a variety of topics to guide you through the playing
of Avendar.  Simply type help '<subject>' to gain help on a certain topic.
Here's a list of general topics you can search for help on to get you
started:

GETTING STARTED - The basics of Avendar and MUDding in general.
INFORMATION - How to get info on yourself and your surroundings.
MOVING AROUND - How to move around in the world of Avendar.
INTERACTION - How to interact with objects and items in Avendar.
COMMUNICATION - How to communicate with others in Avendar.
GROUPING - How to group together with others in Avendar.
COMBAT - How to engage (and survive!) combat in Avendar.
OVERVIEW - An overview of the basic Avendar commands (old help).

Be sure to pay attention to the "See Also" located at the bottom of many of
the helpfiles, as they often point to other useful pieces of information on
the topic you're reading on.

If you are stuck or confused and cannot find help on a certain topic, please
read 'help PRAY' for instructions on how to contact an immortal who may be
able to help you.

<390hp 334m 213mv> 
help information
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Displaying Information                                           |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

There are many types of information available to you, pertaining both to
yourself and your surroundings.  The basic commands to display information
about yourself and your status are:

score, worth, inventory, equipment, description, background, skills, practice

In addition, depending on your class, you may be able to use the following
commands to display information on other abilities you possess:

spells (scholars, templars, druids),
abilities (psionicists),
forms (swordmasters, some templars),
songs (bards)

There are also a number of commands available to gather information and
perceive your surroundings.  These commands are:

look, who, where, scan, exits, time, weather, inspect

As well, you can gather out-of-character information on a few topics via
the following commands:

areas, auto, commands, motd, scroll

Please view the helps for the above commands for details on their purpose
and usages, and test them out on their own.

<390hp 334m 213mv>

<390hp 334m 213mv> 
help skills
/---------------------------------------------------------------------------\
|          Skills and Spells                                                |
\---------------------------------------------------------------------------/

The skills and spells commands are used to display your character's list of
available skills (or spells, as the case may be).  They are listed in order
of level, with mana cost (for spells) or percentage (for skills) listed
where applicable.

See also: CAST

<390hp 334m 213mv> 
The Brintor Road
  The wide dirt way known as the Brintor Road leads north through the Arien
Plains, gashing a brown line through the monotony of the praries.  Deep ruts
carved into the road indicate the passing of carts and caravans seeking
trade with the people of the Brintor Mountains to the north.  South, the
Arien Road leads between Earendam and Var Bandor.

[Exits: north south]

<390hp 334m 211mv> 
clear
The Brintor Crossroads
  The Arien Road stretches endlessly through the plains to the east and
west.  From the north, the wide dirt track known as the Brintor Road cuts
through the prairie, intersecting with the more widely traveled stone
highway.  Deep ruts in the dirt mark the passage of wagon wheels to the
north, toward the Brintor Mountains.  

[Exits: north east south west]
     A sun-bleached signpost stands in the grey soil.
A man of Earendam walks along the road, heading for Var Bandor.

<390hp 334m 211mv>

s
A Ferry Station
  The waters of the Dantaron River flow placidly to the south, a muddy
brown barrier to merchants, carts, and foot travelers.  A small wooden dock
has been erected at the water's edge, and several large ferries run by
riverfolk carry passengers back and forth between the Arien Road and the
outskirts of Var Bandor.  
A wooden sign stands at the edge of the docks.

[Exits: north south]
A ferryman stands on the docks, offering his services for gold.

<390hp 334m 210mv> 
The Dantaron River
  The winding Dantaron River turns to the east, flowing by the city of Var
Bandor.  The placid, muddy waters ripple gently as they run their course,
eventually leading to Earendam eastward.  The stone walls of Var Bandor
tower menacingly to the south, and north and south of the river ferry
stations have been set up.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<390hp 334m 208mv> 
s
The Outskirts of Var Bandor
  You stand outside the north wall of Var Bandor.  In the distance to the
north, the Dantaron river splits into two forks which flow around Var Bandor
on either side.  The ground here is muddy and level, with little grass
growing. Behind you to the south, the stone wall of the city overshadows
the outskirts. 

[Exits: north east south west]
A fisherman hauls along his day's catch.

<390hp 334m 207mv> 
Outside the Northern Gatehouse
  The towering gates of Var Bandor rise to the south.  Huge, heavy wooden
doors reinforced with iron bars, the gates are maintained rigorously.  The
walls to the east and west are solid stone, with murder slits.  To the
north, the river Dantaron splits into two mighty forks which flow by Var
Bandor on either side.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<390hp 334m 206mv> 
Inside the Northern Gatehouse
  This gatehouse house is built behind the gates of Sadrent, the oldest of
the gates into Var Bandor.  Outside, to the north, a ferry leads across the
Dantaron river, while to the south Sadrent road snakes its way into the
city.  The gatehouse is ill-tended, leading in to the poorest section of the
city, and consequently little attention is paid to the traffic of riff-raff
and n'er-do-wells through these wrought iron gates.  

[Exits: north south]
A soldier of the Var Bandor Guard watches the gatehouse.

<390hp 334m 205mv> 
s
Sadrent Road
  Sadrent Road runs the length of northern Var Bandor, winding its way
through the worst parts of town.  Built on the delta when Var Bandor was
founded, the northern buildings are the oldest, and consequently have become
the slum area.  Sadrent Road itself is a wide band of filthy cobblestones
winding between the ruined buildings.  To the east and west is a squalid
alley.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<390hp 334m 195mv> 
s
Center Square
  A burbling fountain dominates the center of the square.  The fountain is
made of gray marble veined with blue.  Large sculptures of dancing otters
and leaping trout, gazing skyward and spouting water from their mouths, sit
within the circular basin.  The rim of the basin appears designed for
seating, but is sprinkled with water.  The square is mortared with rounded
cobblestone radiating outwards from the fountain.  The sounds and smells of
the market and other popular locales nearby mingle in the air.  

[Exits: north east south west]
     A simple pine staff lies on the ground.
     A large marble fountain gurgles peacefully here.
An enforcer of Var Bandor patrols here, scrutinizing every passing face.
A young man clad in soiled clothes grins menacingly at passersby.
A grey pigeon walks about tentatively, looking for scraps of food.
An armed enforcer of Var Bandor stands here.
An armed enforcer of Var Bandor stands here.

e
<390hp 334m 194mv> 
Aragol Street
  Aragol Street bisects the east half of Var Bandor, leading from Center
Square to the docks outside the eastern gatehouse.  Sailors and dockmen
abound in this section of the city, wandering the streets while off-duty. 
The street is composed of well-worn cobblestones, with a few broken and
missing.  To the west is Center Square.  

[Exits: east west]

<390hp 334m 188mv> 
Raddin Street
  Raddin Street, named after an ancient hero from the War of Fire, wends
its way east and west through Var Bandor.  Once a thriving part of town
known for its reputation as a home for men of action, it now serves as the
stomping ground for Var Bandor's cheaper hired swords.  A carved shield
marks the door of an armory to the north, while a hanging sign emblazoned
with a sword calls attention to the weapon shop to the south.  Raddin street
continues to the east, while the main drag of Sadrent road opens to the
west.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<390hp 334m 187mv> 
Raddin Street
  Raddin Street, named after an ancient hero from the War of Fire, wends
its way east and west through Var Bandor.  Once a thriving part of town
known for its reputation as a home for men of action, it now serves as the
stomping ground for Var Bandor's cheaper hired swords.  A small group of men
to the south mill around the mercenary's guild, while a small house lies
north.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<390hp 334m 186mv> 
Raddin Street
  Raddin Street, named after an ancient hero from the War of Fire, wends
its way east and west through Var Bandor.  Once a thriving part of town
known for its reputation as a home for men of action, it now serves as the
stomping ground for Var Bandor's cheaper hired swords.  Raddin Street
deadends at a stone wall to the east, and returns to the west.  North is a
run-down flophouse, and a large tavern to the south is decorated with a sign
proclaiming it to be the Tipsy Swordmaster.  

[Exits: (north) east south west]
A battered and scarred gladiator guards the entrance to the tavern.

<390hp 334m 205mv> 
s
The Tipsy Swordmaster
  The Tipsy Swordmaster is a tavern frequented by the less wealthy
mercenary classes of Var Bandor.  Filled with thick smoke from tobacco
pipes, the large common room of the tavern is filled with the loud sounds of
drinking warriors.  Some scattered tables are filled with boisterous
warriors to the east and west, and the common area is to the south.  Through
some well-travelled doors, the street lies north.  

[Exits: north east south west]

<390hp 334m 204mv> 
e
Scattered Tables
  These scattered wooden tables are filled by warriors, come to the tavern
for its reknowned mead.  Most of the people seated here seem to be grizzled
campaigners - mainly footman and the occasional pikeman from Var Bandor's
standing guard.  The rest of the tavern lies off to the west and south.  

[Exits: south west]
Corporal Garalon of the Var Bandor Guard rests his feet at a table.
